title: Protocols for endothelial cell isolation from mouse tissues: kidney, spleen, and testis
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Kidney endothelial cell isolation
Timing: ∼6 h. For preparation of kidney and glomeruli digestion buffer, 45 min. For digestion of kidney tissue, 1 h 30 min. For gRECs, 1 h. For renal parenchyma ECs: Endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For FACs, 1–2 h.
Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A shows a detailed scheme of kidney EC isolation.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/879-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. EC isolation from mouse kidney and glomeruli
(A) Detailed scheme illustrating isolation of ECs from kidney.
(B and C) Representative FACS plots for gating strategy to sort ECs from kidney glomeruli (B) based on sorting live/CD45-/CD73-/CD102+ cells and from renal parenchyma (C) based on sorting live/CD45-/CD31+ cells.
The kidney EC isolation protocol is designed for separate isolation of glomerular ECs and renal parenchyma ECs (Dumas et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]). The fraction of renal parenchyma ECs still contains some glomerular ECs (as shown in (Kalucka et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]), Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A and 4B) therefore if no pure population of glomerular EC is needed, steps #1b, #1d, #2i, #3, #5b, #5g are optional.
Preparation of kidney and glomeruli digestion buffer
Right before isolation, prepare kidney digestion buffer containing:
HBSS (Ca2+, Mg2+)
0.2% (w/v) collagenase I (Sigma-Aldrich, Cat#C9891)
7.5 μg/mL DNase I
table:files/protocols_protocol_879_3.csv
Prepare fresh PBS-based glomeruli digestion buffer:
Note: We recommend to prepare and pre-warm (at 37°C) glomeruli digestion buffer after step #3c.
80% (v/v) of Trypsin-EDTA 0.25% (final concentration of trypsin: 0.2%)
20 IU/mL Heparin
50 μg/mL DNase I
table:files/protocols_protocol_879_4.csv
Prepare PBS-based Wash Buffer 2.
Right before isolation prepare trypsin neutralization solution:
HBSS (containing Ca2+, Mg2+)
10% (v/v) FBS
table:files/protocols_protocol_879_5.csv
Store prepared buffers and solutions at 4°C until needed.
15 mL of kidney digestion buffer suffices for kidneys from 3 adult mice. 1 mL of glomeruli digestion buffer suffices for glomeruli from 3 adult mice.

Digestion of kidney tissue
Before dissecting kidneys, perform transcardial perfusion via the left ventricle with ice-cold PBS at a perfusion rate of 1 mL/minute for 5 min.
Harvest kidneys. Removing the capsules is optional.
Store kidneys in ice-cold HBSS.
Transfer kidneys to a petri dish containing around 5 mL kidney digestion buffer, cut the kidneys into small pieces (approx. 1-2 mm2) using a scalpel blade and transfer everything into a 50 mL conical tube. Fill up the volume with kidney digestion buffer (e.g., 15 mL for 6 kidneys).
Incubate the sample in digestion buffer for 40 min in a 37°C water bath.
Critical: Shake the tube vigorously by hand every 10 min for faster tissue dissociation.
Critical: After this step, the digestion should be complete (single cell suspension with glomeruli, no macroscopic pieces left). This is critical for the following steps.
Add an equal volume (same volume as digestion buffer) of cold HBSS to stop the digestion.
Filter cell suspension through a 70 μm cell strainer, and wash the conical tube and the strainer once with 5-10 mL of cold HBSS.
Split the flow-through in two equal fractions and filter each fraction using a 40 μm cell strainer: a part of undigested glomeruli remains stacked in the strainers.
Wash the glomeruli on the cell strainers extensively (15 times) with 6 mL of cold HBSS to allow the tubules wash through the strainers → continue to step 3 for isolation of the glomerular ECs.
Centrifuge the filtered cells suspension (flow-through) for 7 min at 300 g, remove the supernatant → continue to step 4 for isolation of renal parenchyma ECs.
Glomerular Renal Endothelial Cells (gRECs)
Transfer the 40 μm cell strainers to a Petri dish.

Collect glomeruli in a 15 mL conical tube by washing the interior of the strainers (upper side of the mesh and inner sides) and collecting from the top of the strainers (with 200 μL HBSS each time for a minimum of 10 times).
Note: Thoroughly inspect the interior of the strainers when collecting the glomeruli: the glomerular material is visible by eye. Wash until no more glomerular material can be seen.
Note: If necessary, in order to collect remaining glomeruli, one could cut out the mesh from cell strainers and immerge filter meshes in 1ml HBSS for additional washing. Additional cell suspension should be transferred to the 15 mL conical tube.
Centrifuge the glomeruli at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Note: After this step, the pellet can be resuspended in 1 mL of HBSS to inspect, under the microscope, the purity of the glomerular suspension. Following by centrifugation at 300 g for 5 min. Typical suspension yields >80% glomerular structures and contaminating remaining tubules, which do not include ECs, therefore their presence doesn’t preclude obtaining a high glomerular EC purity.
Reconstitute and preheat glomeruli digestion buffer for 5 min in water bath at 37°C.
Incubate for precisely 23 min in a 37°C water bath.
Resuspend every 5 min by pipetting up and down with a 1 mL tip.
Neutralize trypsin activity by adding 2 mL of trypsin neutralization solution and dilute up to 10 mL with HBSS.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 400 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL HBSS.
Continue with FACS staining.
Renal parenchyma ECs: Endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads

Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer 1 and add the appropriate volume of CD31 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-097-418) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note: We suggest to resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer 1, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e., for up to 1×107 total cells, resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer 1 and add 10 μL of CD31 MicroBeads. If fewer than 1×107 cells are available, use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1×107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash the cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer 2 and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation prepare collection tubes and LS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-401) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 3 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 3 mL of Wash Buffer 2.
Apply the cell suspension onto the prepared LS column through a 40 μm cell strainer to remove potential cell aggregates in order to prevent clogging of the column.
Wash the LS column 3 times with 3 mL Wash Buffer 2, adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Note: The eluent (CD31-negative fraction) from step #4f can be used to prepare controls for FACS analysis or can be discarded if not further needed.
Remove the LS column from the separator and place it onto a new 15 mL conical collection tube.

Pipet 5 mL Wash Buffer 1 onto the LS column. Immediately flush out the fraction containing the magnetically labeled cells (CD31-positive fraction) by firmly applying the plunger supplied with the column.
Continue with FACS staining.
FACS
Timing: 1–2 h
Critical: Prepare all required controls for flow cytometry analysis beforehand i.e., unstained cell (US) control, viability control (VB), Fluorescence Minus One (FMO) control, isotype controls (optional), as well as the compensation controls (one for each fluorophore) for proper set up of the cytometer.
Note: We recommend to use the cells from the final step of the isolation as the cell controls (US, VB, FMO, isotype controls). However, if the cell number is limited, one can use other cells (e.g., CD31-negative fraction) to prepare the controls. For compensation controls we would recommend to use compensation beads (e.g., OneComp eBeads™ Compensation Beads, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#01-1111-41) to ensure clear fluorescence signal and sufficient compensation.
Centrifuge the glomerular and the renal parenchymal cell suspensions at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the glomerular cell pellet in 0.5 mL Wash buffer 1-based staining solution containing:
CD102 (ICAM-2) Monoclonal Antibody (3C4), e.g.,: CD102/ICAM-2-Alexa647 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A15452) (1:300).
CD73 Monoclonal Antibody (TY/11.8), e.g., CD73-PerCP-Cy5.5 (BioLegend, Cat#127213) (1:100).
CD45 Monoclonal Antibody (30-F11), e.g., CD45-PE-Cyanine7 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#25-0451-82; 1:700).
Viability Dye, e.g. eFluor 450 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#65-0863-18; 1:1000).
Resuspend the renal parenchyma cell pellet in 0.5 mL Wash Buffer 1-based staining solution containing:
CD102 (ICAM-2) Monoclonal Antibody (3C4), e.g., CD102/ICAM-2-Alexa647 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A15452) (1:300).
CD31 (PECAM-1) Monoclonal Antibody (390), e.g., CD31-FITC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#11-0311-82; 1:300).
CD45 Monoclonal Antibody (30-F11), e.g., CD45-PE-Cyanine7 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#25-0451-82; 1:700).
Viability Dye, e.g., eFluor 450 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#65-0863-18; 1:1000).
Stain the cells for 30 min at 4°C in the dark.

Add 3 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and centrifuge the stained cells at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellets in Wash Buffer 1 and proceed with FACS.
For glomerular cells sort viable, CD45- & CD73-, CD102+ cells to the collection tubes.
For renal parenchyma cells sort viable, CD45-, CD31+ cells to the collection tubes.
Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B shows representative FACS plots and gating strategy of viable, CD45-, CD73-, CD102+ glomerular ECs. Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C shows representative FACS plots and gating strategy of viable, CD45-, CD31+ renal parenchyma ECs.
Note: Renal parenchyma ECs are CD102+ and CD31+. Although it is not mandatory to include both antibodies in the staining panel, we highly recommend to do so. In this way, CD102 staining can serve as a control ensuring that the antibody works.
Note: To ensure high viability of the ECs, sort the renal parenchyma ECs to a collection tube containing collection medium (10% (v/v) FBS in PBS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A38401).
Critical: Sort the pure glomerular EC fraction to a collection tube containing Wash Buffer 2. Presence of FBS in collection medium reduces viability of the gRECs after sorting.
Spleen endothelial cell isolation
Timing: ∼6 h 15 min. For preparation of spleen digestion buffer, 45 min. For digestion of spleen tissue, 2 h. For immune cell depletion using CD45 murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For FACS, 1–2 h.
Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A shows a detailed scheme of spleen EC isolation.

Figure 2. EC isolation from mouse spleen
(A) Detailed scheme illustrating isolation of ECs from spleen.
(B) Representative FACS plots for gating strategy to sort ECs from spleen based on sorting live/CD45-/CD11b-/CD31+ cells.
Preparation of spleen digestion buffer
Right before isolation prepare spleen digestion buffer containing:

Supplemented KnockOutTM DMEM-medium (see details in section ‘Materials and Equipment’)
0.1% (w/v) collagenase II
2.5% (w/v) collagenase IV
7.5 μg/mL DNase I
table:files/protocols_protocol_879_6.csv
Prepare PBS-based Wash Buffer 2.
Store the freshly prepared spleen digestion buffer and Wash Buffer 2 at 4°C until needed.
5 mL of spleen digestion buffer suffices for 3 adult murine spleens.
Digestion of spleen tissue
Before dissecting the spleen, perform transcardial perfusion via the left ventricle with ice-cold PBS at a perfusion rate of 1 mL/minute for 5 min.
Grind the harvested spleens in a Petri dish on ice with the rough end of a syringe plunger rod in 5 mL of spleen digestion buffer per 3 spleens.
Transfer spleens with digestion buffer to a 50 mL conical tube.
Incubate sample in digestion buffer in a 37°C water bath for 15 min.
Shake the tube by hand every 5 min for faster tissue dissociation.
Stop the reaction with 12.5 mL of cold Wash Buffer 2.
Filter the sample first through a 100 μm cell strainer and then through a 40 μm cell strainer.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 5 mL of Wash Buffer 2.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1.5 mL of Wash Buffer 1.
Gently apply the cell suspension in a 15 mL conical tube filled with 10 mL of Ficoll and centrifuge at 700 g for 30 min.
Critical: Deceleration of the centrifuge should be performed with low break (SLOW option), or no break in case the slow option is not available on the centrifuge, to not disturb the gradient
After centrifugation, collect the Ficoll part and dilute it up to 50 mL with Wash Buffer 1.

Note: A 5 mL pipette can be used for collecting the Ficoll part.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 10 min, remove the supernatant.
Wash the pellet a second time with 20 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min and remove the supernatant.
Immune cell depletion using CD45 murine MicroBeads
Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer 1 and add the appropriate volume of CD45 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-052-301) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note: We suggest to resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer 1, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd45-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd45-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e., for up to 1×107 total cells, resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer 1 and add 10 μL of CD45 MicroBeads. If fewer than 1×107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1×107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix well and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash the cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer 2 and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation prepare collection tubes and LD columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-901) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ld-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ld-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 3 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 2 mL of Wash Buffer 2.
Apply 2 mL of sample suspension onto one LD column through a 40 μm cell strainer

Critical: collect unlabeled cells (the eluent) in a 15 mL conical tube (this fraction contains ECs) and keep the tube on ice during collection.
Note: 1 LD column is necessary for up to 3 spleens. Step #8d and #8e should be upscaled according to the number of spleens used.
Wash the LD column twice with 1 mL Wash Buffer 2, adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Critical: Collect the eluent to the conical tube from step #8e. This fraction contains ECs.
Centrifuge the total eluent (CD45-negative fraction) at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads
Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer 1 and add the appropriate volume of CD31 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-097-418) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note: We suggest to resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer 1, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e., for up to 1×107 total cells, resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer 1 and add 10 μL of CD31 MicroBeads. If less than 1×107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1×107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash the cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer 2 and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation prepare collection tubes and LS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-401) according to the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 3 mL of Wash Buffer.

Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 3 mL of Wash Buffer 2.
Apply the cell suspension onto the prepared LS column through a 40 μm cell strainer to remove potential cell aggregates in order to prevent clogging of the column.
Wash the LS column 3 times with 3 mL Wash Buffer 2 adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Note: The eluent (CD31-negative fraction) from step #9f can be used to prepare controls for FACS analysis or can be discarded if not further needed.
Remove the LS column from the separator and place it onto a new 15 mL conical collection tube.
Pipet 5 mL Wash Buffer 1 onto the LS column. Immediately flush out the fraction containing the magnetically labeled cells (CD31-positive fraction) by firmly applying the plunger supplied with the column.
FACS
Critical: Prepare all required controls for flow cytometry analysis beforehand i.e., unstained cell (US) control, viability control (VB), Fluorescence Minus One (FMO) control, isotype controls (optional), as well as the compensation controls (one for each fluorophore) for proper set up of the cytometer.
Note: We recommend to use the cells from the final step of the isolation as the cell controls (US, VB, FMO, isotype controls). However, if the cell number is limited, one can use other cells (e.g., CD31-negative fraction) to prepare the controls. For compensation controls we would recommend to use compensation beads (e.g., OneComp eBeads™ Compensation Beads, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#01-1111-41) to ensure clear fluorescence signal and sufficient compensation.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL Wash Buffer 1-based staining solution containing:
CD11b Monoclonal Antibody (M1/70), e.g., CD11b-PE (BioLegend, Cat#101208) (1:500).
CD31 (PECAM-1) Monoclonal Antibody (390), e.g., CD31-FITC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#11-0311-82; 1:300).

CD45 Monoclonal Antibody (30-F11), e.g., CD45-PE-Cyanine7 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#25-0451-82; 1:700).
Viability Dye, e.g., eFluor 450 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#65-0863-18; 1:1000).

Add 3 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and centrifuge the stained cells at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in Wash Buffer 1 and proceed with FACS.
Sort viable, CD45- & CD11b-, CD31+ cells to collection tubes.
Note: To ensure high viability of the ECs, sort the ECs to an Eppendorf tube containing collection medium (10% (v/v) FBS in PBS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A38401).
Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B shows representative FACS plots and gating strategy of viable, CD45-, CD11b-, CD31+ spleen ECs.
Testis endothelial cell isolation
Timing: ∼4 h 15 min. For preparation of testis digestion buffer, 45 min. For digestion of testis tissue, 45 min. For endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads, 45 min. For FACS, 1–2 h.

Digestion of testis tissue

Collect testis and remove the epididymis.

Cut testis in small pieces (1 mm3) with two scalpel blades and transfer to a 50 mL conical tube containing the testis digestion buffer.
Incubate sample in digestion buffer in a 37°C water bath for 20 min.
Shake the tube vigorously by hand every 5 min for faster tissue dissociation.
Stop reaction by adding 25 mL of Wash Buffer 2.
Filter the sample first through a 100 μm cell strainer and then a 40 μm cell strainer.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 10 mL of Wash Buffer 2.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
